item.title: Grading
item.description: The grading will happen twice per year. Dan grading will be done once per year with the help of Stefan Stenudd. The grades will be Aikikai grades. Requirements/Techniques per Grade coming soon

item.title: Contact
item.description: Email address We'll never share your email with anyone else. Subject Message Submit × Yes, the contact form works. I'll get an email, when you press Send. Please don't spam me!

item.title: Privacy Notice
item.description: No cookies, no tracking and no data is created/saved for future marketing. The contact message is send via AWS Lambda, but no data is retained (or even logs created), apart from the email in the dojos inbox, which is deleted after it has been answered.

item.title: Advanced Techniques
item.description: High Fall/Roll Henka Waza - changing techniques Kaeshi Waza - counter techniques Ikkyo and Aiki Ken - sword applications Centering Aiki - joining energies

item.title: Attacks in Aikido
item.description: Grab Attacks Strikes - attacker techniques Aikido against Punches Atemi - striking techniques

item.title: Basic Techniques
item.description: Nikkyo Sankyo Yonkyo Iriminage Shionage Kotegaeshi Tenchinage Kokyunage Kokyuho Ushiro - grips from behind Suwari Kokyuho

item.title: Weapons in Aikido
item.description: Tanto Dori - defence against knife Jo Dori - defence against staff Ken Suburi - basic solo sword exercises Aiki Ken - basic entering exercises Aikibatto - ten duo sword exercises

item.title: Teachers
item.description: Stephan Schroeder: 3rd Dan Aikikai started with Aikido in 2003 while still at university and never stopped. After finishing the university, he moved to Berlin where he continued his training in a dojo that was affiliated with Watanabe Nobuyuki, 8 Dan, (†2018) whose seminars Stephan visited for many years. The thing with Watanabe Sensei was that you probably didn't end up with concrete answers but with very interesting questions.

item.title: Stefan Stenudd
item.description: 7th Dan Aikikai, 4th Dan Iaido Stefan Stenudd is an artist in many ways, a natural leader and gets easily bored. Yet after more that 40 years of Aikido he has yet to become bored by his own Aikido. It’s easy to assume that one got an idea of what Stefan’s Aikido looks like, but prolonged exposure will reveal its wide range and depth. This might partly be explained by a concious effort to avoid one of the trappings of being a teacher: to only teach that which you consider yourself to be “good” in.

item.title: History
item.description: Aikido is a relatively new martial art developed in Japan by Morihei Ueshiba over the course of his life. It's three kanji/letters can be translated as "the way of the harmonizing force". While basically all traditional martial arts have of moral dimension - including the imperative to not do harm (if possible) - this is at the front and center of Aikido. It is therefore more defensive in nature than other martial arts.
